Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Deep Brain Stimulation for Treatment-Resistant Depression

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised controlled trial involved 25 TRD patients

Participants.evidence: 25 TRD patients recruited from two hospitals in the Netherlands. Eligible participants met criteria for major depressive disorder and had not responded to multiple treatment steps.

Intervention.evidence: All patients underwent DBS surgery and participated in a 1-year optimisation phase followed by a 1-year open-label maintenance phase.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of DBS targeted at the ventral anterior limb of the internal capsule (vALIC) in TRD patients.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the response rate (≥50% HAM-D-17 score reduction) after the maintenance phase.

Number_Randomised.evidence: This randomised controlled trial involved 25 TRD patients

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of the 25 patients, 21 entered and 18 completed the maintenance phase.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Eight patients were classified as responders (observed response rate: 44.4%; intention-to-treat: 32.0%).

Harms.evidence: Four serious adverse events occurred, including one suicide attempt, but none were related to DBS.
